channel.title: ASF JIRA
channel.description: An XML representation of a search request

item.title: [AVRO-39] Records with default value generate wrong toString()
item.description: There is an extra quote which needs to be removed.
item.summary: Records with default value generate wrong toString()

status.description: The issue is considered finished, the resolution is correct. Issues which are not closed can be reopened.

item.title: [AVRO-40] Signedness of integers
item.description:
The specification currently says the following:
int: 32-bit unsigned integer
long: 64-bit unsigned integer

I guess this should read "signed" and not unsigned

status.description: The issue is considered finished, the resolution is correct. Issues which are not closed can be reopened.

comments.comment: I just fixed this. Thanks for catching it!

item.title: [AVRO-41] specific and generic instances should implement comparable
item.description: Use of Avro instances with mapreduce would be simpler in many cases if they implemented Comparable.
item.summary: specific and generic instances should implement comparable

status.description: The issue is considered finished, the resolution is correct. Issues which are not closed can be reopened.

comments.comment: Comparable should be implemented consistently with the equals implementation in AVRO-32.
To implement this correctly we need to be able to call ReflectDatumWriter#resolveUnion(). That method should be moved to ReflectData class that inherits from GenericData.

Here's a new version. Ordering is now always consistent with that of the binary comparator (AVRO-108). To do this required a few incompatible API changes:

  • AVRO-110 (making GenericData and ReflectData into singletons)
  • several methods moved from GenericDatumWriter to GenericData, so that they could be shared by the comparator code.
  • adding a getSchema() method to GenericArray, so that it can implement compareTo().
    Tests are added. Unless there are objections, I will commit this.

item.title: [AVRO-42] C++ avro
item.description:
I have a C++ implementation for Avro to contribute. I opened this issue to submit a patch.

Overview:
Serializer/Parser- objects for writing/reading raw binary.
xxxSchema- objects for composing schemas.
ValidSchema- a schema object that has been converted to a parse tree (with some sanity checks).
ValidSchema.toJson() writes the schema as a json object.
ValidatingSerializer/ValidatingParser- check that reads/writes match the expected schema type (more expensive than the raw serializer/parser but they detect errors, and allow dynamic discovery of parsed data/attributes).
Compiler (compileJsonSchema())- converts a Json string schema to a ValidSchema.
Code Generation (experimental) - given a schema it generates C++ objects of the same data types, and the code to serialize and parse it.

What's missing: Defaults are not yet supported. Resolving schema conflicts is not yet supported. And the file and rpc containers are not yet implemented. Documentation, sparse.

status.description: The issue is considered finished, the resolution is correct. Issues which are not closed can be reopened.

comments.comment:
I'm unable to build this on Ubuntu. I installed the requirements with:

sudo apt-get install flex bison libboost-dev

When I type 'make' I get output like:

g++ -Wall -g -I./api -I./parser -I. -isystem/usr/include/boost -MM -MP -MT obj/Zigzag.o -MT obj/Zigzag.d -MF obj/Zigzag.d impl/Zigzag.cc
<built-in>:0: fatal error: opening dependency file obj/Zigzag.d: No such file or directory
compilation terminated.
g++ -Wall -g -I./api -I./parser -I. -isystem/usr/include/boost -MM -MP -MT obj/ValidSchema.o -MT obj/ValidSchema.d -MF obj/ValidSchema.d impl/ValidSchema.cc
<built-in>:0: fatal error: opening dependency file obj/ValidSchema.d: No such file or directory
compilation terminated.

and so on. What am I missing?
Oops, the patch didn't add an obj directory, which the make file expected to already exist. Sorry about that, try 'mkdir obj' in that directory and make again.
I discovered one other step after applying the patch, you'll need to 'chmod +x scripts/gen.py'

Now I get:

g++ -Wall -g -I./api -I./parser -I. -isystem/usr/include/boost -c -o obj/Compiler.o impl/Compiler.cc
In file included from ./api/Schema.hh:4,
from ./api/SymbolMap.hh:7,
from ./api/Compiler.hh:9,
from impl/Compiler.cc:1:
./api/NodeImpl.hh: In constructor 'avro::NodeRecord::NodeRecord()':
./api/NodeImpl.hh:136: error: 'numeric_limits' is not a member of 'std'
./api/NodeImpl.hh:136: error: expected primary-expression before '>' token
./api/NodeImpl.hh:136: error: '::max' has not been declared
./api/NodeImpl.hh: In constructor 'avro::NodeEnum::NodeEnum()':
./api/NodeImpl.hh:146: error: 'numeric_limits' is not a member of 'std'
./api/NodeImpl.hh:146: error: expected primary-expression before '>' token
./api/NodeImpl.hh:146: error: '::max' has not been declared
./api/NodeImpl.hh: In constructor 'avro::NodeUnion::NodeUnion()':
./api/NodeImpl.hh:179: error: 'numeric_limits' is not a member of 'std'
./api/NodeImpl.hh:179: error: expected primary-expression before '>' token
./api/NodeImpl.hh:179: error: '::max' has not been declared
make: *** [obj/Compiler.o] Error 1

There must be a difference in gcc compilers. Mine doesn't seem to care about "#include <limits>" and must include it implicitly. It's possible there are other includes, such as string, that I know are implicit but other compilers may care about. I've tested it with two versions, both of which were > 4.

You can add #include<limits> to the top of api/NodeImpl.hh... but I don't know if you will just encounter the next thing. In the meantime, let me see if i can try some other gcc versions, and create a new patch with the fixes.
With some help from Scott over IM I got this to build & committed it. Thanks, Scott!

item.title: [AVRO-43] Forrest fails in validate schema phase
item.description:
ant doc fails with the following message

[exec]
[exec] validate-sitemap:
[exec] /home/arvindj/downloads/apache-forrest-0.8/main/webapp/resources/schema/relaxng/sitemap-v06.rng:72:31: error: datatype library "http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-datatypes" not recognized
[exec] /home/arvindj/downloads/apache-forrest-0.8/main/webapp/resources/schema/relaxng/sitemap-v06.rng:81:31: error: datatype library "http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-datatypes" not recognized
[exec] /home/arvindj/downloads/apache-forrest-0.8/main/webapp/resources/schema/relaxng/sitemap-v06.rng:96:28: error: datatype library "http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-datatypes" not recognized
[exec] /home/arvindj/downloads/apache-forrest-0.8/main/webapp/resources/schema/relaxng/sitemap-v06.rng:102:28: error: datatype library "http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-datatypes" not recognized
item.summary: Forrest fails in validate schema phase

status.description: The issue is considered finished, the resolution is correct. Issues which are not closed can be reopened.

comments.comment: It's because you're using JDK 6. You need to use JDK 5 to run forrest.
One must specify java5.home to run the 'ant doc' target.

item.title: [AVRO-44] clean target fails until c is first built
item.description: The 'ant clean' target fails until 'c' is first built. This is annoying for folks like me who primarily do not develop in C and who frequently use commands like 'ant clean test-java'.
item.summary: clean target fails until c is first built

status.description: The issue is considered finished, the resolution is correct. Issues which are not closed can be reopened.

comments.comment:
This patch will make sure that "make clean" is only called if the c makefile has been generated.

Sorry for the inconvenience.
Only run "make clean" for the C code if the C Makefile has been generated.
